text:
Another point is that most of the content “written by” the higher-ups is actually ghostwritten by freelance writers - what you see may not reflect their actual writing abilities. 

Agree that it would probably be an easier process to interview and then hire writers to write. 

Writers also aren’t personally attached to the content - so the flesh out and the edits won’t be as extensive.

elements.text:
Another point is that most of the content “written by” the higher-ups is actually ghostwritten by freelance writers - what you see may not reflect their actual writing abilities. 

Agree that it would probably be an easier process to interview and then hire writers to write. 

Writers also aren’t personally attached to the content - so the flesh out and the edits won’t be as extensive.

text:
If you wrote a post in September 2020 and the content / advice is still timely, then updating the title will work.

How deep you go will be informed by the goals of the piece and its performance so far. E.g if the post gets lots of traffic but a high exit rate then you want to update the title, subheadings, content (depth and topics covered) and this may or may not affect the length of the post.

It all depends on the goals of the blog post and if there's anything you can do to improve its performance to achieve those goals. Hope this helps.

elements.text:
If you wrote a post in September 2020 and the content / advice is still timely, then updating the title will work.

How deep you go will be informed by the goals of the piece and its performance so far. E.g if the post gets lots of traffic but a high exit rate then you want to update the title, subheadings, content (depth and topics covered) and this may or may not affect the length of the post.

It all depends on the goals of the blog post and if there's anything you can do to improve its performance to achieve those goals. Hope this helps.

text:
When updating content I usually look for:

• Any out-of-date information or references that can be updated (links, stats, etc.)?
• New information that the reader cares about that can be added (e.g. if you had a list post on '_Best Email Marketing Platforms 2020_', there may be new entrants worth mentioning in 2021, or some that went out of business that need removing)
• Go through Search Console queries for the page to see if there are relevant queries we're not fully answering
• Product updates/features that can be integrated into the post
• Has the search intent changed and can you address that? E.g. if you had a post on '_Guide to the 2020 US Election_' it would look need to look different today than it pre-election because because search intent has changed around it and people are looking for different info.
• I always update the Published or Last Modified date

elements.text: When updating content I usually look for:
Any out-of-date information or references that can be updated (links, stats, etc.)?
New information that the reader cares about that can be added (e.g. if you had a list post on '
Best Email Marketing Platforms 2020
', there may be new entrants worth mentioning in 2021, or some that went out of business that need removing)
Go through Search Console queries for the page to see if there are relevant queries we're not fully answering
Product updates/features that can be integrated into the post
Has the search intent changed and can you address that? E.g. if you had a post on '
Guide to the 2020 US Election
' it would look need to look different today than it pre-election because because search intent has changed around it and people are looking for different info.
I always update the Published or Last Modified date

text: <@UUJBMDVGB> I love your approach. Bookmarking this.
MarketMuse wrote an interesting article about the importance of Information Gain: <https://blog.marketmuse.com/content-writing-for-information-gain/>

attachments.title: Content Writing for Information Gain
attachments.text: Writing me-too content isn't the way to position yourself as a thought leader or rank well in Google. There's a good chance you're making that mistake. Here's how to avoid it.
attachments.fallback: MarketMuse: Content Writing for Information Gain

elements.text: MarketMuse wrote an interesting article about the importance of Information Gain:

text: (to differentiate your content from what’s currently out there — because most content optimization tools will lead you down a path that’ll just encourage you to do what your competition did. And that’s too easy to copy, you should be looking to create a “content moat”)

elements.text: (to differentiate your content from what’s currently out there — because most content optimization tools will lead you down a path that’ll just encourage you to do what your competition did. And that’s too easy to copy, you should be looking to create a “content moat”)

text: <@U01704F04QH> Funnily enough, the first time I encountered this "story" model was an article about Justin Bieber in 2016. I'm not a Justin Bieber fan, not even a little. But I read the whole article about him and was in awe of the writing when the piece was finished. Surprised (ashamed?) that I had spent so much time reading about him, I went back and analyzed Caity Weaver's writing. After that, I started noticing it in other people's work (science writer Ed Yong at _The Atlantic_ comes to mind with all of his Covid work in 2020). But, honestly, had it not been for something as ridiculous as Justin Bieber ... I'm not sure the "story" component would have been so obvious. This is the piece, in case you're curious. It's a wild ride of an article: <https://www.gq.com/story/justin-bieber-gq-interview>

text: Forms might be cost effective, but I think the challenge you might run into with that is some people going into PR-style scripts with their answers. You'll need someone who can ask follow-up questions, let a little awkward silence happen in a conversation, etc.

text:
I'm working on solidifying a content calendar with/for a client, and we're looking for a good way to manage social media posting.

What's your favorite scheduling, management, tracking, etc. tool for social? It would be extremely helpful to have one with comprehensive hashtag management and discovery, as well.

What's your favorite scheduling, management, tracking, etc. tool for social? It would be extremely helpful to have one with comprehensive hashtag management and discovery, as well.

text:
Help I need advice! I posted recently about running social media and branding for a band. They are good friends of mine and while they are well established and have been around 25 years wjrh a dedicated following, they are putting out new music (on an established label) for the first time in 8 years. My questions are... I’m a very experienced social media/content person and did a very thorough audit of all their needs. They def need help getting all their platforms optimized correctly, then creating  a social media editorial calendar, writing it, executing it, monitoring, etc. they want to know what I would charge and we’ve agreed on a retainer as best approach versus hourly. I just know they don’t have a ton of money so my normal fee of like $50-$75 per hour would prob not work. 

I’m thinking something like $500 a month seems reasonable even though that’s way low but I’ve asked them to make me an offer and see if that works. But just looking for any other pricing advice. Thanks! And there would be lots of perks as concerts pick back up with tickets and festivals and what not...

elements.text: Help I need advice! I posted recently about running social media and branding for a band. They are good friends of mine and while they are well established and have been around 25 years wjrh a dedicated following, they are putting out new music (on an established label) for the first time in 8 years. My questions are... I’m a very experienced social media/content person and did a very thorough audit of all their needs. They def need help getting all their platforms optimized correctly, then creating  a social media editorial calendar, writing it, executing it, monitoring, etc. they want to know what I would charge and we’ve agreed on a retainer as best approach versus hourly. I just know they don’t have a ton of money so my normal fee of like $50-$75 per hour would prob not work.

I’m thinking something like $500 a month seems reasonable even though that’s way low but I’ve asked them to make me an offer and see if that works. But just looking for any other pricing advice. Thanks! And there would be lots of perks as concerts pick back up with tickets and festivals and what not...

text:
Are there any revenue streams attached to social or digital that you could get a revenue cut from? Then it's less a "pay me and hopefully it works" and more of a "I win when you win" thing. I'd have a flat fee built in vs going 100% revenue cut though.

OR if they're actually incorporated, talk about equity? No idea how that works when it comes to music and bands though :sweat_smile:

text: Hello! Not all of our members are guys. In an effort to be more conscious of the language we use to address each other, why not try “Hey, folks,” or “Hey everyone” instead?
